Food consumption represents the social construction of selves and bodies. Food ways and food talks—where (not) to eat, what (not) to eat, how (not) to eat, and with whom (not) to eat—are tied closely with religious lives and faith. In their daily lives, people often observe religious restrictions on diet that come from particular religious faiths such as Islam, Buddhism, and Hinduism. People also restrict and regulate their diets because of non-religious faith, through practices of veganism, vegetarianism, pescetarianism, and so on. The aim of this course is to provide students with opportunities to ethnographically examine food and diet in everyday lives and the roles that food and diet play in the formation of self-identities and (non) religious faiths. In order to build a theoretical foundation, we will read rich anthropological studies on the consumption, production, and circulation of foods, and critically engage with questions about how foods play a role in shaping people’s religious lives, personal faiths, and ethnic identities.

This course examines the importance of theories of visual culture to learning and teaching modern South and Southeast Asian history. The main objective of the course is to promote the critical use of visual research methods in the development of new historical studies. As such, it introduces academics, students and researchers to media research skills required when exploring the ideologies conveyed by the visual dimension of modern South and South East Asian history. The first part of the course provides a comprehensive introduction to theories of visual studies and theories of perception. In the second part, the course surveys critical debates about the complementarity between traditional text-based historiography and visual literacy. The course draws extensively on the unique collections of visual records held by the Royal Commonwealth Society Collections and the Centre of South Asian Studies (Cambridge), the National Archives (London), and the Imperial War Museum (London). The course covers key historical events from the 1860s onwards and examines the visual constructions of space, culture, gender and race relevant to the areas of India, Pakistan, Nepal, the Himalayas, Sri Lanka, Burma, Malaya, Singapore and Hong Kong. Most specifically, it offers a critical overview of how historical and cultural identities have been (mis)represented across specific visual narratives, from paintings, drawings, posters, advertisements to amateur films, documentaries, newsreels, feature, ethnographic and animation films. Each lecture in this course explores a selection of such visuals in relation to key events and social developments in this region’s history. Occasionally, interview excerpts selected from the Centre of South Asian Studies (Cambridge) and from the Imperial War Museum’ (London) oral history archives complement the visual case studies.
Visual Anthropology and Theories of Self-representation
Visual Anthropology and Theories of Self-representation
历史文化学院（旅游学院）

This course offers the students a unique opportunity to explore and asses the ways in which theories of visual anthropology are fundamentally relevant to the development of scholarship concerned with issues of self-representation and identity building. Questions pertaining to the study of modern and contemporary visual narratives within traditional cultural frameworks such as, for instance, European, Middle Eastern, South and South East Asian societies, are discussed in great detail for their impact on new methodologies and theoretical perspective within visual anthropology – a discipline gradually gaining central stage in the humanities and social sciences. Moreover, the course addresses the critical enquiry of how theories of self representation can be used in advancing new understandings of today’s global identities across allegedly common visual rhetoric, from twentieth-century paintings to twenty-first century digital practices. The course inscribes the use of archival and contemporaneous visual records within current theoretical and methodological frameworks exploring, in particular, key debates and themes in modern European, Middle Eastern, and South and South East Asian history. It draws on the conflicting relation between established historiography and visual anthropology and on theories of perception and self-representation for their inherent potential for confirming and/or challenging traditional text-based research resources. Most importantly, the course contributes to the debate about traditional means of historical investigation of the Self and of identity constructions, and develops a comparative program in which the students can compare and discuss a great variety of visual records pertinent to major historical themes and events.

The course will consist of 16 hours of lectures covering the funerary archaeology, of the Western Europe and further afield. The course will focus on specific sites, but also on themes that have been of particular importance in funerary archaeology in recent years. Nie Er: Composing Sonic Nationalism and China'S Revolutionary Music
历史文化学院（旅游学院）

This course, based on the instructor’s forthcoming book about Nie Er, is divided into two parts. In the first week I trace the composer's life and his ideas about music to examine two influential paradigms--revolution and modernization/modernity--that have dominated Western scholarship on 20th century Chinese history. Inspired by mass songs from the Soviet proletarian music movement and Chinese folk songs, coupled with his use of modern and distinctively Chinese style of music. This study thus stands as a useful corrective to growing literature on the construction of a Chinese modernity, which has privileged the consumer culture of Shanghai and consciously sought to displace a previous historiography that focused on the Chinese revolutionary experience. In the second week, I examine the process by which Nie Er became a national music icon. We will analyze the relationship between the politics of commemoration and the development of sonic nationalism, in both its textual and performative dimensions. I examine Nie Er's commemoration from 1935 to the present day, showing how the use of a barometer of political trends in Republican China and the PRC. The content of the course is base on new cultural history methods and new research on Chinese nationalism, especially its sonic dimensions, which have largely been overlooked by scholars. The course readings include the instructor's forthcoming manuscript, selections from Nie Er's writings and music, as well as secondary sources on Chinese revolution.

In this course, we investigate Leonardo’s art for these courts, focusing on the social and political context of works ranging from the famous Last Supper, to the portrait of Cecilia Gallerani, to the monumental equestrian statue celebrating the military prowess of Duke Francesco Sforza. We also examine Leonardo’s imaginative battle machines and engineering projects, and survey the sometimes surprising projects that the artist was required to design. Leonardo painted, and but he engineered bridges, organized astrologically-themed entertainment, and devised a life-sized, mechanical lion (a Renaissance robot).This course will end by investigating the ways that Leonardo’s reputation was shaped at court. By analyzing the legends that followed his death – including the myth that Leonardo died in the arms of King Fran？ois I of France – we can learn more about the fundamental importance of Leonardo da Vinci and Italian Renaissance art for modern constructions of artistic creativity and genius.

In recent decades, some art historians of Renaissance Italy have turned attention from painting and sculpturetoward a wide variety of objects and media, including those commonly dismissed as merely decorative arts. In this course, we critically examine a number of artfully crafted Renaissance things – what art historians now call material culture – including radiant clothing and textiles, lavishly painted wedding chests, politically significant medals, exquisite metalwork and jewelry, and widely-collected prints. We will study how these expensive and carefully crafted art objects were made, valued, collected, and displayed. We will see, also, that their raw materials came from far beyond Italy, from throughout the Mediterranean, and from Asia and the Americas. We will examine audiences and markets for art, and likewise modes of artistic production, that have only recently been appreciated by historians. By studying material culture, we gain much insight on Italian Renaissance society, and we can look at Renaissance art from new perspectives.

疾病医疗社会史作为新社会史的一个分支,虽然在目前尚无一明确而清晰的概念予以界定,但总体来看,其主要以历史上的疾病医疗为切入点,通过探讨疾病医疗与历史的互动关系来考察社会文化的变迁。在西方,疾病医疗社会史的研究兴起于上个世纪六七十年代,至今已初具规模;而在中国,海峡两岸则是在八、九十年代才被部分学者予以关注并开始付诸研究的，由于起步较晚,我国大陆的相关研究还相当薄弱。开设此课程有助于开拓学生视野，将历史拓展到更多的学科交叉中进行研究。在大陆的医史学界，以往有关疾病史的研究大多是探讨疾病本身，少有从疾病与社会的角度探讨的。作者之所以选择这门课，不仅是想从疾病医疗的角度勾勒中国近世独特的社会变迁脉络，其最终目标更希望能进一步探讨中国社会的近代化特质。因此，本课程在探讨医疗的基础上，特别关注以下的课题：中国近世社会的发展脉络、国家与社会的关系及社会的特质等

本课程包括(1)介绍目前医疗社会史的研究仅仅限于对个别地区的某种疾病做研究，缺乏全面性的研究；(2)缺乏有关生态问题深入而细致的研究；(3)目前研究仅局限于国家与社会对疾病的响应，甚少对病人及病家心态的研究；(4)对疾病爆发流行的原因，未能做到结合传染病流行的三要素──传染源、传播途径和易感人群的深入研究；(5)研究人员的医学与疾病学修养有待提高；(6)对白喉和疫喉痧等清代常见的疾病甚少研究；(7)数据运用上，医书和笔记文集的利用有限，仍局限在以往大陆的医史和历史学界，对于欧美盛行以久或台湾近年来新刊的疾病、医疗与社会的研究的掌握仍有待加强

新文化史是20世纪60-70年代在欧美兴起的一场史学方法与理论的革新运动。1999年中国掀起了研究新文化运动史的热潮。新文化史吸收了“自下而上”的社会史研究思想，借鉴人类学等其他学科成果，形成独特的研究范式——以文化及其意义为对象，开展跨学科研究，以讲故事的方式从事微观考察，从而拓展了史学研究领域。然而新文化史也存在弊端，如探讨对象的不明晰、研究取向的碎片化、客观历史的否定性，遇到了发展的瓶颈。另外，新文化史传入中国后，与社会史相结合，被称为社会文化史，仍有待于深入挖掘。开设本课程有助于开拓历史学学生更为广阔的视野。社会文化史强调的是，在具体的研究实践中将社会史分析和文化史诠释结合在一起。在分析社会现象时，不能忽视相关人群对这些现象的理解或这些现象之于当事人的意义，唯有如此，社会史分析才不致死板、僵硬；在诠释文化现象时，不能忽视这些现象背后的社会关系和权力关系，唯有如此，文化史诠释才不致空泛、玄虚。本课程的开设旨在引导学生透过社会现象深入分析中国历史的深层脉络

Tourism Visual Image Communication and Design
历史文化学院（旅游学院）
本课程的要义是学习、掌握视觉形象在旅游业中传播的规律、特征，把握旅游视觉文化及视觉审美形式，使学生能够熟练掌握旅游视觉形象的设计与研究方法。
本课程主要论述旅游视觉形象的基本概念、旅游视觉传播的目的及特点，视觉语言、数字技术的运用和形态，色彩情感的把握，视觉形象的基础设计要素、表现及程序，广告、纪念品、形象网站、景观与城市标识、服务人员等视觉形象的设计与研究方法\x07
民宿客栈的个性化经营
历史文化学院（旅游学院）

成都番茄来了科技有限公司成立，公司创始人为陈俊。他曾任腾讯西南大区总监，曾获得全国职业经理人Top100等荣誉。2013年毅然放弃百万年薪开始创业，开发番茄来了免费客栈管理系统。黄镜为该公司副总经理。该公司通过丰富的市场调研前提下，开设“番茄来了”公司——通过PC端+移动端同步管理，帮助运营者在线上快速办理入、离店登记，完成房态、订单、用户、渠道、财务等信息管理。此为当前旅游行业新起的一种新的商业模式，通过开设此课程既可以让学生了解旅游业的最新动态，又可以分享到行业领域内企业家创业的丰富经验。目前，全球超过500多个旅游目的地，近2万家特色住宿从业者选择了“番茄来了”。，2015年，“番茄来了”继续扩大了市场规模，将用户数扩大到了5万家。通过开设该课程旨在使学生与旅游行业人士近距离交流沟通，将旅游的课本知识和实践积极结合，以便更深刻的理解旅游业中引用的各种理论方法并在此基础上有所创新。
主要围绕番茄来了科技有限公司创始起，如何进行网络平台的设计操作，并依托此系统进行民宿客栈的全面信息管理的讲解，在具体介绍“客栈的市场细分”、“客栈的个性化经营”等内容。
